comment_body.16:
Any solid competitors to the 235i/240i manual?

I'm a fan of the speed, the sound, the luxory features, the light weight, the handling, the modern looks, and brand but am insisting on the manual which is really hard to find a good deal on anywhere in the US. I think the mk3 audi tt is a good competitor but unfortunately it doesn't come in manual. The 435 is heavier and honestly more common than the 235. The manual 435 is equally hard to find anyway.

The boxster is also a good competitor in my eyes but it's slower and more expensive.

comment_body.22:
Trying to decide between 2020 Kia Forte 5 EX and 2019 Mazda 3 sport GS + lux package

Looking at buying a car pretty soon but am stuck between 2 fairly different cars. In BC, Canada for reference.

Forte 5 EX: getting offered at $23,300 (this includes freight) + tax would be around $26k CAD. Sale would come with: - lifetime free oil changes - 6 month free payments - 0.99% financing for 60 months - Lock nuts and rubber mats - no spare tire but offering roadside protection for 5 years - all other EX features on website (manual seats, car play, lane assist etc.)

Mazda 3 sport GS + lux: current offer is at $31,500 CAD after taxes and fees, have not really spoken about add-ons etc, this should be happening tomorrow. this package would include: - 0% financing for 72 months - lux package includes sunroof, leatherette and power seats, blind spot detector, lane assist, carplay etc. - will talk about adding in accessories in the coming days

Basically my question is, does the Mazda warrant the added cost? Both cars are in our budget and we like the features they offer. Just not sure if the Mazda is $6k (really closer to 10k with the 6 months no payment) better than the Kia.

Any input would be appreciated! (Sorry about formating on mobile)

I did like the Fiat 500x but it's so small.

We go to the car show every year so I feel like I've considered every vehicle on the market. Additional Notes: I had an Infiniti G35 for 11 years and I loved driving it. I sold it in 2018 because I was living in the city, taking public transportation to work, barely drove it, could use my SO's car for groceries, etc.

About 6 months later I got a new job where I needed to drive (of course) so I ended up getting a 2016 V6 Accord, and honestly, I hate it. It's not fun to drive, it feels clunky. Don't get me wrong, it's a perfectly nice car and it has a lot of great features. It's just not for me. My husband is a real Honda fan and he talked me into getting a great deal on the car, but ugh, I regret buying it.

So I've basically been looking for a new car since I bought that. I think one thing I loved about my G35 was that it was RWD. I'd love to recreate that feeling. But now we have a kid, so I can't exactly make a sports car my daily driver.

I'm leaning toward SUV because it's easier on my back to get the kid and stuff in and out of the car, but still looking for something that's exciting(-ish) to drive
